items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Water levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses as a result of persistent heavy rain. Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land in locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near these watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. The level of the lake is expected to remain above this flood alert threshold into the coming weekend. We are monitoring the situation and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated later today 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ehen, Rive Calder, River Irt, River Esk

items.message: River levels remain high at the Egremont river gauge as a result of the persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Ennerdale Bridge, Cleator Moor, Cleator, Egremont, Beckermet, Braystones, Calder Bridge, Holmrook and Bootle areas. High river levels remain possible on the River Wyre, Distington Beck, Pow Beck, River Ehen, River Keekle, Skirting Beck, Whangs Beck, Kirk Beck, River Calder, River Irt, River Esk, River Annas and their tributaries. Further rainfall is forecast today 29/10/21 and over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking and clearing debris screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated later today 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Greta, St Johns Beck and Bassenthwaite Lake

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Greta, St Johns Beck, Glendermackin

items.message: River levels will continue to be high at the Keswick Camp Site river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. The areas we expect to be affected are the Mungrisdale, Threlkeld, Keswick, Portinscale, Braithwaite, Bassenthwaite and Wythop Mill areas. River and lake levels will remain high on the River Glenderamackin, St Johns Beck, River Greta, Naddle Beck, Cuddy Beck, River Derwent, Newlands Beck, Coledale Beck, Bassenthwaite Lake, Halls Beck, Chapel Beck, Wythop Beck and their tributaries. Rainfall eased overnight but further rain is expected today 29/10/21 and over the weekend, meaning that levels will remain steady but high throughout for this period. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated later today 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels are still raised at the Fitz Bridge river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Dunnerdale, Duddon Bridge, Broughton-in-Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Soutergate, Coniston, Ulverston, Dalton-in-Furness and Barrow-in-Furness areas. High river and lake levels are possible on the River Duddon, Kirkby Pool, Soutergate Beck, Church Beck, Yewdale Beck, Coniston Water, River Crake, Town Beck, Dragley Beck, Poaka Beck, Mill Beck and their tributaries. There is some further rain forecast for today 29/10/21 and over the weekend and so river levels are expected to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking watercourses for blockages. Please avoid contact with floodwater and avoid low-lying roads and footpaths near rivers. This message will be updated later today 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.
River levels have fallen on the rivers Wampool and Ellen after rainfall has eased.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message: River levels will remain high and steady on the Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent due to the persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding to low lying land and roads remain. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Buttermere, Lorton Valley, Cockermouth, Branthwaite, Bridgefoot, Camerton, Barepot and Workington areas. Further rain is forecast today 29/10/21 and over the weekend. High river levels will remain on the River Cocker, Whit Beck, River Derwent, River Marron, Lostrigg Beck and their tributaries. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated later today 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high after recent prolonged rain. Rainfall has eased but there is some further rainfall  forecast over the next few days and so river levels are expected to remain steady but high today, 29/10/21. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Staveley, Ings, Burneside, Kendal, Garnett Bridge, Stainton, Sedgwick, Holme, Beetham and Milnthorpe areas. High river levels are possible on the Rivers Kent, Gowan, Sprint, Mint, Stock Beck, Stainton Beck, Peasey Beck, Farleton Beck, River Bela, Holme Beck and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated later today 29/10/21 or as the situation changes.
River levels have now fallen and are not forecast to reach flood alert level again today.

River and lake levels are high as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last few days. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Bampton, Patterdale, Glenridding, Dockray, Pooley Bridge, Dacre, Eamont Bridge and Penrith areas. High river and lake levels are possible on the River Lowther, Haweswater Beck, Goldrill Beck, Grisedale Beck, Glenridding Beck, Aira Beck, Ullswater, River Eamont, Dacre Beck, Thacka Beck and their tributaries. There is some further rain forecast today and over the weekend and so levels are likely to remain raised. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded. This message will be updated later today 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: Water levels remain high on Lake Windermere, Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, particularly from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands which includes low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel due to the recent persistent rainfall. This has eased in some locations overnight but further spells of rain are forecast today 29/10/21 and over the weekend and levels will remain high. We are monitoring the situation and our staff have been checking defences and unblocking debris screens where needed. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated later today, 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rothay at Grasmere, White Bridge and Stock Lane

items.message: The level of Derwent Water remains high following recent heavy rainfall. With showers forecast for the next few days lake levels are forecast to fall slowly. Areas at risk of flooding include low lying land bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This Flood Warning is expected to remain in place for several days as the levels will remain high. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message by 5:00 pm today the 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen but remain high at the Linstock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Crosby-on-Eden, Linstock, Carlisle and Rockcliffe areas. High river levels remain on the River Eden, River Caldew, River Petteril, Durranhill Beck, Brunstock Beck, Gosling Sike, Little Caldew, Parham Beck, Rockcliffe Beck and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are checking rivers for blockages. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated later today, 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Greta at Keswick, Keswick Campsite, Rugby Club and Quinta
items.message: Whilst river levels have peaked and rainfall has eased, river levels remain high at the Keswick Camp Site river gauge as a result of recent persistent heavy rainfall.  Further showers are forecast this morning and consequently, the risk of flooding to property, roads and farmland remains. Flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying roads, residential, commercial properties and campsites in Keswick adjacent to the Rivers Greta and Derwent. Including Greta Park Rugby Football Ground, Keswick Campsite, Keswick School Sports Field, Keswick Show Field and Playing Field areas. We continue to closely monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message by 5:00 PM today,  29/10/2021.

items.description: River Kent at Burneside, Steeles Row and Carling Steps

items.message:
River levels will start to fall this afternoon as rainfall eases.
No property flooding is expected.
The forecast is for limited further rainfall for today.
River levels will start to fall.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels are high but steady on the River Lune and River Conder due to rainfall.
Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow morning and river levels at Caton gauge are expected to rise again tomorrow afternoon.
Flooding tomorrow, 30/10/2021, is forecast to affect locations near the River Lune and River Conder, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Lune, Conder and Keer and other watercourses from Kirkby Lonsdale to Galgate including Gressingham, Carnforth, Hornby, Wray, Bentham and Lancaster.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
This message will be updated by 07:00 PM on 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ehen at Egremont, Bleach Green, Ennerdale Mill, Bridge End, Vale View, Wood Bank, Rugby Club
items.message: While river levels have peaked and rainfall has eased, river levels remain high on the River Ehen due to recent persistent rainfall. River levels have been falling overnight but are forecast to rise again towards a second, lower peak around 3:00 PM this afternoon 29/10/2021.  Areas that continue to be at risk are locations near the River Ehen, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties adjacent to the River Ehen at Egremont, including the Bleach Green, Ennerdale Mill, Bridge End, Vale View, Wood Bank and Rugby Club areas. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message by 4:00 PM this afternoon, 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Cocker and Derwent at Cockermouth, Cricket Ground and Trout Hotel Car Park
items.message: Whilst river levels have peaked and rainfall has eased, river levels remain high on the Rivers Cocker and Derwent due to recent persistent heavy rainfall. Areas that remain most at risk include commercial and residential properties adjacent to the Rivers Cocker and Derwent at Cockermouth, in the Brewery Lane, Bridge Street, Crown Street, High Sand Lane, Main Street and Waterloo Street areas. Whilst river levels remain high we will keep all flood gates closed in the area and will continue to monitor. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will update this message by 04:00 PM today 29/10/21.

items.description: River Derwent at Workington, Seaton Mill and Barepot
items.message: Whilst river levels have peaked and rainfall has eased, river levels remain high on the River Derwent due to recent heavy rainfall. Areas that continue to be at risk include residential and commercial properties at Seaton Mill, Barepot, Hall Park, Hall Park View, Workington Police Station, Leisure Centre, Bowling Green and Cricket Club. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message by 5:00 PM today 29/10/2021.

items.description: River Leven at Newby Bridge and Backbarrow
items.message: River levels remain high following prolonged rainfall and some further rain is forecast for today, Friday 29/10/21.Flooding is expected at properties adjacent to the River Leven at Newby Bridge and Backbarrow, including the Swan Hotel, Boat Houses, Mill Farm, The Whitewater Hotel, Water Close, Lakeland Village, Coach House and Levens Dale. We continue to closely monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message this afternoon by 16:00 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high following prolonged rainfall, and as a consequence, Windermere Lake levels continue to rise slowly. Flooding is expected to remain a risk to low lying commercial and residential properties, camping, caravan sites and leisure facilities on the shores of Windermere today Friday 29/10/21. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will update this message this afternoon by 16:00 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Marchington Brook, Picknall Brook, Rolleston Brook

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible overnight Friday into Saturday. Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Rivers Clyst and Culm area and further rain is expected. This will mean that the Rivers Clyst, Culm and their tributaries will rise. Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from Friday evening. We expect rivers to remain high throughout the night into Saturday. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Saturday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Plym, Tory Brook, Long Brook

items.message:
Flooding is possible throughout today, Friday 29th October, and into Saturday due to persistent and heavy rainfall. Following the rainfall overnight, catchments are saturated and river levels remain high.

Overnight widespread rainfall resulted in totals over 40mm with intense rain of more than 80 mm over high ground. This has led to rivers rising rapidly and flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers. While River levels have peaked they remain high ahead of rainfall forecast for this evening and in to the early hours of Saturday morning. Additional flood warnings may be issued for some locations.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area ready to clear blockages as required. This message will be updated on Friday 18:00 or earlier if the situation changes

River levels remain high on the River Tweed at the Norham gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall yesterday, 28/10/2021. Consequently, flooding of riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads between Carham and Union Bridge is still possible today, Friday 29/10/2021.
River levels have now peaked and will fall throughout the day. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 18:00 today, 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ullswater and River Eamont at Pooley Bridge, Ullswater Steamer Pier to B5320 Bridge
items.message: River and Lake levels remain high at the Pooley Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is possible. Flooding is expected to affect properties on the B5320 between Dunmallard Hill and the River Eamont, including the Steamer Pier. We expect levels to remain high today 29/10/21, with some further rain forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation and our staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying roads and footpaths near the lake and rivers. This message will be updated this afternoon by 16:00, or as the situation changes.

This will mean that the River Umberleigh will rise. Bankfull conditions are expected with some localised riverside field flooding from Friday evening. We expect rivers to remain high throughout the night in to Saturday. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. floodArea.riverOrSea: River Barle, River Exe, River Lyn, River Mole, River Bray

items.message: Flooding is possible overnight Friday in to Saturday. Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Exmoor Rivers area and further rain is expected. This will mean that the Rivers Barle, Lyn, Mole, Bray and upper River Exe will rise. The main areas of concern are Simonsbath, Brushford, Withypool and Dulverton, where levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from Friday evening. We expect rivers to remain high throughout the night in to Saturday. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Saturday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
We have seen a limited response in the rivers at the top of the catchment from last nights rain. The rain is clearing during today, 29/10/21, however we could see some showers throughout the day and further rain tomorrow morning, 30/10/21.
River levels at the top of the catchment have started to fall slowly but remain higher than normal. Saturdays rain could see limited response with levels being similar to those experienced last night.

The flood alert for the Upper River Wharfe is no longer in force. Rainfall totals came in lower than was forecast on Thursday 28th October and river levels did not rise as high as expected. Further rain is expected today, Friday 29th October, and over the weekend. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will re-issue the flood alert if it is required. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

River levels remain high at the Donyatt and Ashford Mill river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 29/10/21.  We expect flooding to affect roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. The lower River Parrett is forecast to be bankfull and overtopping could occur.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight, into tomorrow morning 30/10/21. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend.  We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Saturday, 30/10/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, River Tone

items.message: River levels remain high at the Bishops Hull river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 29/10/21.  We expect flooding to affect roads around Hillfarrance, Bradford on Tone, Lane End Road at Ham and the Creech St Michael to Henlade road. Bradford on Tone ringbanks will be bankfull.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight, into tomorrow morning 30/10/21. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend.  We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Saturday, 30/10/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels remain high at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 29/10/21.  We expect flooding to affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries.  Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight, into tomorrow morning 30/10/21. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Saturday, 30/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the River Rye and tributaries is no longer in force. Rainfall totals came in lower than was forecast on Thursday 28th October and river levels did not rise as high as expected. Further rain is expected today, Friday 29th October, and over the weekend. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will re-issue the flood alert if it is required. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Tavy from Mary Tavy to Lopwell
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
The risk of flooding from the River Tavy has now reduced as river levels have fallen through the morning and water from Thursday evening/Friday morning’s flooding is draining naturally from low lying areas. 
Conditions remain unsettled with further rain forecast for Friday evening which is expected to result in a further response. The Flood Alert for this area is still in force and will be updated throughout the day to reflect the latest forecast overnight. 

We continue to monitor conditions and if risks increase overnight, this Flood Warning may be reissued in response.

We have seen a limited response in the rivers from last nights rain. The rain is clearing during the day. We could see some showers this evening and into Saturday morning. Frequent showers are likely to spread in from the north-west from late on Sunday and into Monday across the north of England and Wales.

Frequent showers are likely to spread in from the north-west from late on Sunday and into Monday across the north of England and Wales.

items.description: Barnstaple, Braunton, Ilfracombe and Combe Martin area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Caen, Bradiford Water, River Yeo

items.message: Flooding is possible overnight Friday in to Saturday. Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the North Devon area and further rain is expected. This will mean that the Rivers Caen, Bradiford Water and Yeo and coastal streams from Braunton to Combe Martin will rise. The main areas of concern are Barnstaple, Braunton, Ilfracombe and Combe Martin, where levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from Friday evening. We expect rivers to remain high throughout the night in to Saturday. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Saturday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

The main areas of concern are Gribbleford Bridge, Passaford and Hatherleigh, where levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from Friday evening. items.description: River Torridge (Lower) from Dolton to Bideford, including Taddiport and Weare Giffard
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected from around 11pm on Thursday continuing into Friday morning.

Heavy rain has been falling in the Torridge area throughout Thursday evening. This has caused the River Torridge to rise.
Properties and low lying areas in Taddiport (properties around Taddiport Bridge, Sewage Treatment Works and B3227) and Weare Giffard (riverside properties and roads), will start to flood first from around 11pm on Thursday evening. River levels will be at their highest between 1am and 5am.

Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.

We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible throughout today, Friday 29th October, and into Saturday due to persistent and heavy rainfall. Following the rainfall overnight, catchments are saturated and river levels remain high. 

Overnight widespread rainfall resulted in totals over 40mm with intense rain of more than 80 mm over high ground. This has led to rivers rising rapidly and flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers. While River levels are currently peaking they remain high ahead of rainfall forecast for this evening and in to the early hours of Saturday morning. Additional flood warnings may be issued for some locations.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area ready to clear blockages as required. This message will be updated on Friday 18:00 or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Lyd from Sydenham to Lifton

items.description: River Tamar from Greystone Bridge to Cotehele excluding Calstock
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected from Friday morning. Take immediate action.

Heavy rain has fallen over the Tamar catchment with further bands of rainfall expected throughout the day. This has caused the River Tamar to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising over the next 2-3 hours.

Properties and low lying areas around Bradstone Mill, Tutwell, Gunnislake, Morwellham Power Station and Cotehele will start to flood first. River levels are expected to remain high throughout the day, peaking around noon. Additional rainfall is expected this evening which will see a further response. 

Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing, and roads could form flow routes. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 or earlier if the situation changes. Our staff are out in the area and will relay information and assist the emergency services and council.

items.description: River Clyst from Broadclyst to Clyst St. Mary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected on Friday morning.
Heavy rain has been falling in the River Clyst area throughout Thursday evening and into Friday morning. This has caused the River Clyst to rise and the river will remain high for the next couple of hours before levels begin to fall later on Friday.
There is likely to be deep road flooding in the Burrow, Broadclyst Bridge, Clyston Mill, Dymond's Farm and Sowton Barton areas and flooding to properties and farms between Clyst St. Mary and Topsham including Newcourt Barton and Cotts Farm. River levels will be at their highest between 06:30am and 10:00am.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible overnight Friday into Saturday. Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Exe area. This will mean that the River Exe will rise. Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from Friday evening. We expect rivers to remain high throughout the night into Saturday. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Saturday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Hay-On-Wye river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is occurring.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye 2.2m to 2.4m  this afternoon, Bredwardine 4.2m to 4.4m this afternoon, Belmont 4.3m to 4.5m this evening, Old Wye Bridge 3.9m to 4.2m this evening, Mordiford 3.8m to 4.2m over night, Ross on Wye 3.0m to 3.5m Tomorrow 30/10  
 We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend with further rainfall expected. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  this evening, 29/10/2021 by 19:00, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is occurring.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland.   
 We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend with further rainfall expected. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 7pm this evening 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers in the Forest of Dean
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling, the risk of flooding from last nights localised heavy rainfall has now reduced.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
Some further rainfall is forecast over the coming weekend.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

The flood alert for North Sea coast at Bridlington has now been issued. Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of strong winds and high waves. The particular areas of concern are Bridlington South Pier between 12:30 and 16:30 and Bridlington Lifeboat Station between 11:30 and 15:30 on Friday 29th October. Please take care around exposed promenades and roads where spray may create hazardous conditions. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Onibury river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is occurring.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include  Church Stretton and Ludlow. Predicted peaks:-  Onibury 1.7m to 1.8m this afternoon 29/10.
We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend with further rainfall expected. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 7pm this evening 29/10/2021 or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Mordiford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of farmland is expected by 18:00 today 29/10/2021.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. Predicted Peaks:- Ross on Wye 3.1m to 3.5m at midday on 30/10/2021, Lydbrook 3.4m to 3.8m in the afternoon on 30/10/2021.   
  We expect river levels to remain high until 30/10/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  this evening, 29/10/2021 by 19:00, or as the situation changes.
